course.title: IBM MQ Operations and Administration for z/OS
course.prerequisites: Completion of the Interskill IBM MQ Operations and Administration course or equivalent practical knowledge of IBM MQ fundamentals.

modules.title: MQ Installation and Configuration on z/OS
modules.description: This module covers the installation and configuration of IBM MQ on z/OS, focusing on z/OS-specific datasets, procedures, and components that differ from traditional MQ environments.

sections.title: Using SMP/E to Install MQ on z/OS
sections.overview: IBM MQ for z/OS is installed using System Modification Program/Extended (SMP/E), a z/OS-specific tool for managing software installation and maintenance.
key_steps: Receive the MQ product using SMP/E’s RECEIVE command.
Apply the installation using APPLY CHECK and APPLY.
Accept the installation with ACCEPT to make it permanent.
sections.example: GIMSMP //SMPJCL DD * SET BDY(GLOBAL). RECEIVE SYSMODS.
sections.difference_from_traditional_mq: Traditional MQ (e.g., on Linux) uses package managers like rpm or apt, whereas z/OS relies on SMP/E for dataset-based installation.

sections.title: Early Code
sections.purpose: Early code enables testing of MQ features before general availability.
sections.usage: Installed in a separate SMP/E target zone for isolated testing.
sections.example: Define a test queue manager with early code to validate new channel features.

sections.title: IBM MQ Console
sections.description: A web-based interface for managing MQ objects on z/OS, replacing some traditional TSO/ISPF tasks.
sections.access: Configured via z/OS HTTP server, accessed at http://<host>:port/ibmmq/console.
sections.difference_from_traditional_mq: Traditional MQ often uses MQ Explorer, while z/OS emphasizes the IBM MQ Console for centralized management.

sections.title: Queue Manager and Channel Initiator Procedures

queue_manager_jcl.description: Defines datasets for logs, page sets, and BSDS.

channel_initiator_jcl.description: Starts the channel initiator for distributed queuing.

sections.difference: Traditional MQ uses command-line scripts (e.g., crtmqm, strmqm), while z/OS uses JCL for batch execution.

sections.title: Logging, Bootstrap Dataset, and Page Sets

logging.description: z/OS uses active and archive logs stored in VSAM datasets. Dual logging enhances reliability.

sections.difference: Traditional MQ uses file-based logs, while z/OS leverages VSAM for high-performance storage.

sections.title: Buffer Pools and System Parameters

zparm_library.description: Contains system parameters (e.g., CSQZPARM) for queue manager customization.
zparm_library.example: Set LOGLOAD=500000 for log checkpoint frequency.

sections.difference: Traditional MQ uses configuration files (e.g., qm.ini), while z/OS uses ZPARM datasets.

sections.title: Queue Sharing Groups (QSGs)
sections.description: Enables multiple queue managers to share queues via the z/OS Coupling Facility.
sections.difference: Unique to z/OS, leveraging Parallel Sysplex for high availability, unlike traditional MQ’s single-queue-manager model.

modules.title: MQ Operations and Resources on z/OS
modules.description: This module focuses on operating MQ on z/OS, mapping commands, managing resources, and using z/OS-specific utilities.

sections.title: Mapping MQ Commands to z/OS
sections.overview: MQSC commands are issued via z/OS console or ISPF, unlike traditional MQ’s command-line interface.
examples: z/OS: F CSQ1MSTR,DISPLAY QMGR via z/OS console.
sections.difference: z/OS integrates with system console and JCL, while traditional MQ uses shell scripts.

sections.title: Issuing MQSC Commands
sections.console: Use MODIFY (F) command, e.g., F CSQ1MSTR,DEFINE QLOCAL(MYQUEUE).
sections.ispf: Use CSQOREXX panels to issue MQSC commands interactively.
sections.example: Display queue status: DISPLAY QUEUE(MYQUEUE) ALL.

sections.title: Managing MQ Resources Using ISPF
sections.description: ISPF Panels: Provide a menu-driven interface for managing queues, channels, and listeners.
sections.navigation: Access via CSQOREXX exec, select queue manager, and manage objects.
sections.difference: Traditional MQ relies on MQ Explorer or scripts, while ISPF is z/OS-specific.

sections.title: Issuing MQ Commands from Batch Jobs
sections.description: CSQUTIL: Batch utility for queue management tasks.
sections.use_case: Automate queue backups or object definitions.

sections.title: Starting and Stopping Queue Manager and Channel Initiator
z/OS-Specific MQ Commands
examples: DISPLAY QSG to view queue sharing group status.
RECOVER BSDS to restore Bootstrap Dataset.
sections.difference: These commands leverage z/OS Coupling Facility, unavailable in traditional MQ.

sections.title: Managing MQ in a Coupling Facility Structure
sections.intra_group_queuing: Enables queue manager communication within QSG without channels.

modules.title: MQ Security, Monitoring, and Performance
modules.description: This module covers securing MQ resources, monitoring queue manager activity, and optimizing performance on z/OS.

sections.title: Security

authenticating_users.description: Use RACF to define MQ resources.

sections.encryption: Use Advanced Message Security (AMS) for message-level encryption.
sections.difference: z/OS integrates with RACF, while traditional MQ uses OS user authentication or MQ-specific profiles.

sections.title: Monitoring and Messages
sections.queue_manager_messages: Logged to z/OS console, e.g., CSQ9022I for successful command completion.
sections.interpreting_messages: Use IBM MQ Messages manual to decode, e.g., CSQJ103E for log issues.

sections.title: MQ Traces
sections.format_trace: Use CSQWDMP to format trace records.
sections.difference: z/OS traces integrate with SMF, unlike traditional MQ’s file-based traces.

sections.title: SMF for Statistics and Accounting
sections.enable_smf: Set STATIME=30 in ZPARM for 30-minute intervals.
sections.analysis: Use CSQ6SYSP to extract SMF data.
sections.example: DISPLAY SMFSTATS to view real-time stats.

sections.title: Performance Optimization
key_areas: Buffer Pools: Increase buffers for high-throughput queues.
Log Management: Optimize LOGLOAD to reduce checkpoints.
Channel Tuning: Adjust BATCHSZ and DISCINT for channel performance.
sections.difference: z/OS performance leverages Coupling Facility and VSAM, unlike traditional MQ’s file system optimizations.

modules.title: MQ Queue Sharing Groups
modules.description: This module covers the creation, configuration, and management of Queue Sharing Groups (QSGs) in IBM MQ for z/OS, focusing on setup for multiple Queue Managers in a Sysplex, leveraging Coupling Facility and DB2 for high availability.

sections.title: Introduction to Queue Sharing Groups
sections.overview: QSGs enable multiple Queue Managers to share queues and messages within a z/OS Sysplex, using Coupling Facility (CF) and DB2 for data sharing and high availability.
sections.benefit: Improves scalability and failover by allowing shared queue access across Queue Managers.

sections.title: Prerequisites for QSG Setup
requirements: IBM MQ 9.2 or later on z/OS in a Sysplex.
Access to a Coupling Facility with defined structures.
DB2 data-sharing group for shared queue storage.
sections.automation: Use tools like Ansible, Python, or REXX to script setup.

sections.title: Defining a QSG
sections.mqsc_command: ALTER QMGR QSGNAME(QSGA) to assign a QSG name to Queue Managers.
sections.example: Run on each Queue Manager (e.g., QMGR1, QMGR2) via z/OS console or ISPF.

sections.title: Configuring DB2 for Shared Queues
sections.description: Configure a DB2 data-sharing group (e.g., DB2GRP1) for storing shared queue data.
sections.automation: Automate JCL updates for CSQZPARM using scripts.

sections.title: Defining Coupling Facility Structures
sections.description: Define CF structures (e.g., QSGA_ADMIN, QSGA_APPL) in the Sysplex CFRM policy for queue and admin data.
sections.utility: Use CSQ5PQSG to define QSG structures.

sections.title: Enabling QSG on Queue Managers
sections.description: Update CHINIT parameters and restart Queue Managers to join the QSG.

sections.title: Defining Shared Queues
sections.purpose: Allows multiple Queue Managers to access the same queue.

sections.title: Testing and Monitoring QSGs
sections.testing: Put and get messages on shared queues from multiple Queue Managers.
sections.monitoring: Use SMF 115/116 records or IBM MQ Console to verify performance and access.

sections.title: Naming Conventions and Limits
sections.cf_structure: Up to 16 characters, starting with QSG name (e.g., QSGA_ADMIN).
sections.max_qmgrs: Up to 32 Queue Managers per QSG, constrained by CF and DB2 capacity.
